repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Problem: On the page: https://neovim.io/doc/user/dev_vimpatch.html The links extend beyond the container and thus end up behind the navigation to the right. Solution: Adding these lines to get_help_html.lua solves the problem: white-space: normal; word-wrap: break-word; Before: After:

comment_data.body: One minor thing: The comment here doesn't agree with the new CSS attribute value (see #24151), because we no longer have `white-space: pre`, though `margin-bottom:0` apparently is still needed in both cases.

yes this needs to be fixed.
```suggestion
      /* Text following <pre> is
```
I believe that I have updated the pull request with these changes. If I have misinterpreted anything, please let me know.

comment_regular_data.body: Thanks for your contribution on improving docs! It would be appreciated if you could [describe the problem](https://lamport.azurewebsites.net/pubs/state-the-problem.pdf) this PR is trying to fix, and/or [provide more explanation about why this change would be needed](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages). Screenshots (before v.s. after) would also work in this particular case.

> Thanks for your contribution on improving docs! It would be appreciated if you could [describe the problem](https://lamport.azurewebsites.net/pubs/state-the-problem.pdf) this PR is trying to fix, and/or [provide more explanation about why this change would be needed](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages). Screenshots (before v.s. after) would also work in this particular case.

Description together with before and after images have been added.

We can try this. But the purpose of not wrapping was to avoid wrapping codeblocks and other lines that should not be wrapped. The fact that the right-column menu occasionally gets in the way is not a big deal, but people seem to care about it... (why does it matter if you see the last bits of a gigantic URL?)

> why does it matter if you see the last bits of a gigantic URL?

For starters it looks like ass
And, more concretely, as the screenshot shows, it interferes with the navigation (TOC). So this is an actual usability issue.
That could be solved by making the ToC opaque. But on big screens (or short ToC), there is no readability issue and no "looks like ass" issue.
Well, yes, if there is no issue, there is no issue.

title: docs(gen_help_html.lua): wrap legacy help at word-boundary
